title: 103_hr5247
content:
There is no information provided in the prev_chunk to assist with summarizing the curr_chunk. The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission can extend the time for construction commencement for specific projects by up to 2 years upon licensee request. This authorization will end 3 years after enactment. The Commission may consolidate extension requests and must report to Congress on projects with multiple extensions, detailing reasons for delays and licensee compliance with construction requirements under the Federal Power Act. SEC. 2. REINSTATEMENT

The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission is authorized to reinstate a hydroelectric license for Project No. 7829 effective May 23, 1993, with construction to commence within 4 years. The authorization will terminate 3 years after enactment.

SEC. 3. EXEMPTION OF PORTION OF EL VADO HYDROELECTRIC PROJECT FROM LICENSING REQUIREMENT. The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission may exempt the 69 KV transmission line from certain provisions of the Federal Power Act to allow the Northern Rio Arriba Electric Cooperative to effectively use its system in conjunction with the El Vado Hydroelectric Project license. The exemption must be applied for within 120 days of the enactment of the Act and will be granted promptly unless deemed not in the public interest. SEC. 4 amends the Energy Policy Act of 1992 to require the Commission to grant exemptions for certain projects in Alaska. The Commission must report to Congress on actions taken and provide explanations for any failures to grant exemptions. SEC. 5 pertains to a legislative report on Hawaii. The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission will recommend legislation to transfer authority for licensing new hydroelectric projects in Hawaii to the state, while ensuring compliance with federal environmental laws and regulations. This transfer will not apply to projects conflicting with National Wildlife Refuges or National Parks in Hawaii, and aims to avoid setting a precedent for other states or territories. The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission will recommend legislation to transfer authority for licensing new hydroelectric projects in Hawaii to the state, while ensuring compliance with federal environmental laws and regulations. The Commission will also obtain views from other states and federal environmental agencies, including Hawaii, Guam, the Virgin Islands, and Puerto Rico, and include these views in their report to Congress. SEC. 6. Size limitations of eligible facilities under PURPA are amended by changing the year from 1994 to 1996.
